channel.title: External Static IP
channel.description: I was wondering how I could get a External Static IP (not internal)

item.title: External Static IP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:33, topic:302027”]pretty sure no dns server takes a week to update unless you set the ttl on the domain to like 2073600

even then i would hope it ignores it :p[/quote]
I’ve seen one take that long before; but notice I said only one ;).

Read full topic

item.title: External Static IP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Starting up …, post:31, topic:302027”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=398362.msg2960162#msg2960162 date=1253135696]

[quote author=Starting up … link=topic=398362.msg2960155#msg2960155 date=1253135434]

[quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=398362.msg2959686#msg2959686 date=1253074761]

If you are using a dynamic IP (it appears you are) you want to get a no-ip set up pointing to your IP, then instead of doing what mopman said, you want to create a CNAME record pointing to your no-ip on your registrar’s DNS interface.
[/quote]Set up a CNAME record pointing to my.no-ip.org and downloaded the no-ip DUC and still doesn’t work.

What “doesn’t work”?
[/quote]I used a proxy to go to mydomain.com and it didnt work.

Perhaps the DNS servers that the proxy server is hosted on didn’t update yet.
[/quote]Its been a few weeks, still doesn’t work.[/quote]
Some shitty DNS servers take a long time to update (weeks :). Try using a different proxy server?

Read full topic

item.title: External Static IP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Starting up …, post:21, topic:302027”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=398362.msg2958135#msg2958135 date=1252968922]

their point (although why the hell they don’t just say it i don’t know) is that when you register a domain, almost all registrars give you a dns service anyway

there is no real need to host your own dns unless you want to do something special

Exactly, not to mention hosting your own is more prone to problems and you can’t move things around as much.

You just need to use the DNS you are provided with your domain registrar, if you want something else, use https://www.editdns.net/
[/quote]What would I point the DNS with my domain registrar to?
EDIT: Won’t let you change it to a IP.[/quote]
You point the DNS server entries to DNS servers that point your domain to an IP. A registrar doesn’t let you set an IP address if they don’t offer DNS hosting (with that package)…

Read full topic

item.title: External Static IP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Starting up ...:

Alright DNS (Domain Name Servers)… I might be wrong so feel free to correct me, but a domain needs something to point to i.e a dns?

Domain -> DNS (nameserver) -> IP.

When you type ‘google.com’, you query your ISP’s (or other DNS servers) for what ‘google.com’ corresponds to.

user@COSMOS:~$ nslookup google.com
Server:	 208.67.222.222
Address:	 208.67.222.222

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:    google.com
Address: 74.125.127.100

208.67.222.222 being one of the DNS server(s) I use and the reply being what said domain resolves to.

Read full topic

item.title: External Static IP
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:14, topic:302027”]You don’t need to set up DNS.

And to set up a mail server ‘apt-get install postfix’[/quote]
Exactly, the OP has no need for a DNS server; especially, with a single host.

[quote=“Starting up …, post:15, topic:302027”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=398362.msg2957898#msg2957898 date=1252962075]
You don’t need to set up DNS.

And to set up a mail server ‘apt-get install postfix’
[/quote]But I don’t wanna use like a 3rd party :[/quote]
What? You’ll be using a 3rd party for your registrar anyway… (which the ones I mentioned also sell DNS hosting). I don’t think you truly understand what DNS means.

Read full topic

item.title: External Static IP
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Starting up ...:

I get frustrated and confused really easy :… Plus I really didnt understand the DNS part still don’t…

There is no DNS part, you don’t have to worry about it or do anything about it at all.

If you can install debian or ubuntu, just type ‘sudo apt-get install apache2’ and there you are, web server all set up.

If you have any operating system, download xampp (google it) and unzip it, click run and then you have a full web server stack.

Read full topic
